Description: THE FISH EGGS TO FRY: ECO-SCHOOL USA SALMON STEWARDS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE K-12 SCHOOLS IN THE PORTLAND-METRO REGION, SPECIFICALLY TARGETING FOUR UNDERSERVED SCHOOLS (GRADES 3RD-5TH) IN THE NORTH CLACKAMAS SCHOOL DISTRICT, ALONG WITH FAMILY AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS INVOLVED IN WATERSHED LEARNING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE JOHNSON CREEK AND CLACKAMAS WATERSHEDS. THESE FOUR SCHOOLS INCLUDE TWO TITLE 1 SCHOOLS AND TWO WITH HIGHER PERCENTAGES OF ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS AND STUDENTS OF COLOR. THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE SCHOOL-BASED TEAMS IN MEANINGFUL PROJECT-BASED LEARNING THAT CONTRIBUTES TO A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF AND STEWARDSHIP OF WATERSHEDS WITHIN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN. IT WILL INTEGRATE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (ODFW) FISH EGGS TO FRY PROGRAM WITH THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION'S (NWF) ECO-SCHOOLS USA SALMON STEWARDS BY TRAINING EDUCATORS, PROVIDING SCHOOL SEED GRANTS, AND ENGAGING STUDENTS IN MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES

THE PORT TOWNSEND SCHOOL DISTRICT (PTSD) WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE JAMESTOWN S'KLALLAM TRIBE TO DELIVER HIGH QUALITY PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO TEACHERS AND DELIVER LONG-TERM CLASSROOM INTEGRATED MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES (MWEE) FOR STUDENTS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND CONNECTED TO THE SINCE TIME IMMEMORIAL CURRICULUM. TEACHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN A TWO-DAY SUMMER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, FOLLOWED BY TWO PROJECT PLANNING SESSIONS, AND DISTRICT WIDE PROFESSIONAL LEARNING SESSIONS THROUGHOUT TWO SCHOOL YEARS. THIS TRAINING WILL PROVIDE NOAA RESOURCES, LESSON PLANS, AND ACTIVITIES, COMBINED WITH BACKGROUND KNOWLEDGE TO PREPARE 15 TEACHERS TO PROVIDE MWEES FOR APPROXIMATELY 720 PTSD STUDENTS, AT SEVEN GRADE LEVELS FOR TWO YEARS. THE TOTAL AUDIENCE OVER TWO YEARS OF THE GRANT IS 30 TEACHERS AND 1000 PTSD STUDENTS. THE PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL BE  SHARED WITH EDUCATORS AT A NATIONAL CONFERENCE AS A MODEL FOR PLACE-BASED WATERSHED EDUCATION.

THIS PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE A SYSTEM WIDE INCREASE IN EQUITABLE AND INCLUSIVE 3RD GRADE SCIENCE EDUCATION AND WATERSHED STEWARDSHIP ENGAGEMENT FOR STUDENTS IN WENATCHEE, WASHINGTON. TEACHERS WILL CONFIDENTLY IMPLEMENT SCIENCE TEACHING THROUGH MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEE), IMPROVED CURRICULUM, AND STRATEGIES TO BETTER SERVE STUDENT POPULATIONS; ESPECIALLY ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS (ELLS). STUDENTS WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE ABOUT LOCAL SALMON PHENOMENA, WEATHER & CLIMATE ISSUES, AND ANIMALS OF THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST THROUGH TIME, WHILE PARTICIPATING IN FIELD INVESTIGATIONS AND INFORMED STEWARDSHIP ACTIONS. THIS FUNDING WILL EXPAND ON CASCADE FISHERIES' PREVIOUSLY FUNDED 2021 B-WET PROJECT AND PROVIDE CONTINUED STUDENT MWEES AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (PD) AND SCIENCE TEACHING SUPPORT FOR WSD'S 3RD GRADE TEACHERS. TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES WILL EMPOWER TEACHERS TO DELIVER AN ENHANCED BILINGUAL MWEE-INTEGRATED CURRICULUM CONFIDENTLY AND ENTHUSIASTICALLY THROUGH THREE SCIE

PROJECT PROPOSED BY SAGINAW CHIPPEWA INDIAN TRIBE: NINKCHIWAAWENINDIMIN - "WE HONOR EACH OTHER" WILL HELP STUDENTS FROM SAGINAW CHIPPEWA ACADEMY, SAGINAW CHIPPEWA INDIAN TRIBE'S K-5 SCHOOL, TO MAKE DIRECT CONNECTIONS TO THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHED THROUGH LOCALLY RELEVANT SCIENCE AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS A K-5  WATER WALK AND 5TH GRADE FIELD TRIPS TO LEARN ABOUT THE GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEM. STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN STUDENT-LED, CROSS-CURRICULAR, MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES THAT CONNECT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS ON LOCAL WATERSHEDS, NATIVE PLANTS AND WILDLIFE TO TRADITIONAL, INDIGENOUS LIFEWAYS. THEY WILL ALSO DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECTS. EXAMPLES OF POTENTIAL ACTION PROJECTS AND ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PLANTING/RESTORING PROTECTIVE VEGETATION; REMOVING INVASIVE SPECIES; CLEAN-UP EFFORTS; AND PLANTING TRADITIONAL MEDICINES AND OTHER VEGETATION THAT CONNECTS STUDENTS WITH ANISHINAABE LIFEWAYS, TRADITIONS, AND FOODS. STUDENTS MAY ALSO CHOOSE

PROJECT PROPOSED BY MICHIGAN TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY: BRAIDING KNOWLEDGE SYSTEMS FOR INCREASED EARTH AND CLIMATE LITERACY:  "INAWENDIWIN: CONNECTION, OBSERVATION, & LEARNING TOGETHER" WILL ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 20 TEACHERS AND 600 STUDENTS FROM FIVE COUNTIES IN THE 1842 CEDED TERRITORY OF MICHIGAN'S WESTERN UPPER PENINSULA IN A VARIETY OF MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES). BUILDING UPON PREVIOUS SUCCESS RECRUITING RURAL SCHOOL PARTICIPATION, THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE GREAT LAKES INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE HOLDERS, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND THE BROADER PUBLIC IN EXPLORING THE INTERSECTION  BETWEEN TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, EARTH SYSTEMS PROCESSES, PEOPLE, AND CLIMATE  IMPACTS. AREAS OF INQUIRY FOCUS ON ISSUES IDENTIFIED BY THE KEWEENAW BAY INDIAN COMMUNITY (KBIC) INCLUDING HUMAN MIGRATION, CHANGING ANIMAL POPULATIONS, INVASIVE SPECIES, CHANGES IN  HARVEST SEASONS, DROUGHT, WATER VALUATION, AND ACCESS TO FOODS AND MEDICINES. PROJECT PROPOSED BY INTER-TRIBAL COUNCIL OF MI (ITCMI): CREATING MEANINGFUL AND CULTURAL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR THE STUDENTS OF THE OJIBWE CHARTER SCHOOL WILL PROVIDE MEANINGFUL AND CULTURAL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS WHO ATTEND OJIBWE CHARTER SCHOOL. OCS IS IN BAY MILLS INDIAN COMMUNITY, 20 MILES WEST OF SAULT. STE. MARIE, MI. AN ESTIMATED 120 3RD-12TH GRADE STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN THIS PROGRAM. THE 2023-2024 SCHOOL YEAR PROJECT LEADS WILL PREPARE THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM AND ENGAGE EDUCATORS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND LESSON PLANNING. THE STUDENT PROGRAM WILL BEGIN AT THE START OF THE 2024-2025 SCHOOL YEAR. THE PROGRAM WILL OFFER STUDENTS SIX OUTDOOR EXPERIENCES AND ONE UNIQUE TOUR OF A FISH HATCHERY. STUDENTS WILL VISIT THREE LOCAL WATERSHEDS, MEASURE WATER QUALITY, AND COMPARE AND CONTRAST RESULTS FROM EACH WATERSHED. STUDENT LESSONS WILL INCLUDE LEARNING ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE AND EXPLORING INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE (ITEK).

PROJECT PROPOSED BY RED CLIFF BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA INDIANS AND UW-MADISON' EARTH PARTNERSHIP INDIGENOUS ARTS AND SCIENCES: NIBI GAA-GIKINOO'AMAAGE, NIBI GAA-BIMAAJI'IWEMAGAK (WATER WILL TEACH, WATER WILL GIVE LIFE) II WILL ENGAGE RED CLIFF BAND YOUTH AND THE EDUCATORS WHO SERVE THEM AT BAYFIELD SCHOOL DISTRICT IN CULTURALLY-DRIVEN WATERSHED EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP ACTION ALONG LAKE SUPERIOR. A SEASONAL LEARNING FRAMEWORK OF TRADITIONAL OJIBWE SKILLS AND HARVEST ENGAGES PARTICIPANTS IN CULTURALLY-INTEGRATED WATERSHED EXPLORATION THAT CONNECT THE LOCAL PUBLIC SCHOOL TO THE LARGER COMMUNITY. HANDS-ON LEARNING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTION HIGHLIGHT THE INTERSECTIONS OF WATERSHED HEALTH, CLIMATE RESILIENCE, AND CULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY. MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES WILL LINK OJIBWE LANGUAGE AND CULTURE TO LOCAL WATERSHED LEARNING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTION IN ALL SEASONS, FOCUSING ON: MANOOMIN (WILD RICE) HARVEST AND FISHING (FALL); STORYTELLING, WILDLIFE MONITORING, TRADIT

SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY NONPROFIT ONE COOL EARTH PROPOSES A TWO-PART PROJECT TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR TEACHING CLIMATE LITERACY IN THE CLASSROOM. FIRST, ONE COOL EARTH WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION OF AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION COALITION TO INCREASE CLIMATE LITERACY AT A COUNTY LEVEL, AND SECOND, ONE COOL EARTH WILL UNDERTAKE STRATEGIC PLANNING TO INCREASE INTERNAL CAPACITY TO REACH ADDITIONAL SCHOOLS WITH CLIMATE LITERACY PROGRAMMING AND IMPROVE PROGRAM IMPACT AT 29 SCHOOLS COUNTY-WIDE.

CLIMATE CHANGE ACROSS THE CURRICULUM (CCAC) WILL SUPPORT TK-5 TEACHERS IN SONOMA AND MARIN COUNTIES TO WORK WITH SCIENTISTS, COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND CLASSROOM EDUCATORS TO INTEGRATE CLIMATE CHANGE INTO EXISTING CURRICULA. THIS "TRAIN THE TRAINERS" PROGRAM WILL SHIFT THE EXISTING MODEL FOR CLASSROOM CLIMATE EDUCATION AND TEACHER PROFESSIONAL LEARNING AWAY FROM ADDRESSING CLIMATE CHANGE AS A DISCRETE TOPIC, AND INSTEAD WILL USE AN INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH THAT ENGAGES TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN LEARNING AND LOCAL STEWARDSHIP OPPORTUNITIES IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS. THIS WORK WILL SCALE UP AS LEAD TEACHERS WORK AS MENTORS TO THEIR COLLEAGUES AS WE ENGAGE COHORTS OF TEACHERS IN THE PROGRAM.

FOR THIS PROJECT, SEQUOIA RIVERLANDS TRUST IS APPLYING ON BEHALF OF THE SEQUOIA ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION DIRECTIVE (SEED) TO HIRE A PART-TIME COORDINATOR. THIS COORDINATOR WILL WORK WITH S.E.E.D. MEMBER ORGANIZATIONS, AS WELL AS LOCAL EDUCATORS, ADMINISTRATORS, DISTRICTS, AND OTHER FOR-PROFIT AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS IN TULARE COUNTY TO CREATE A FRAMEWORK FOR LOCALLY-RELEVANT CLIMATE-RELATED CURRICULUM FOR GRADES K-12. BY DOING SO, THE COORDINATOR WILL BRING TOGETHER MANY ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS TO BUILD A NETWORK OF STAKEHOLDERS INTERESTED IN THE FUTURE OF CLIMATE LITERACY IN THE REGION. THIS PROGRAM WILL ONLY SERVE TO INCREASE EQUITABLE AND MEANINGFUL ACCESS TO CLIMATE-RELATED CURRICULUM AND RESOURCES, NOT ONLY TO RESOURCES PROVIDED BY THE S.E.E.D. NETWORK BUT ALSO TO NATIONAL RESOURCES AVAILABLE THROUGH NOAA, THE EPA, AND OTHER RELATED ORGANIZATIONS, AND WILL INCREASE CAPACITY OF TEACHERS TO PROVIDE MEANINGFUL CLIMATE- RELATED EDUCATION TO YOUTH IN THE COUNTY. THIS WILL ALS

WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AN IMMERSIVE 5-DAY ENVIRONMENTAL/CLIMATE LITERACY PROGRAM FOR MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, PRIORITIZING STUDENTS FROM DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES, AND CULMINATING IN DIRECT CAPACITY BUILDING ASSISTANCE FOR LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS TO DELIVER THE PROGRAM EQUITABLY. IN THE FIRST YEAR OF THIS 3-YEAR PROGRAM, CLC WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER THREE 5-DAY SESSIONS AND A TRAIN-THE TRAINER/PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM (T3/PD). IN YEAR 2, TRAINED GRADUATES WILL DELIVER THREE 5-DAY SESSIONS WITH CLC ASSISTANCE. IN YEAR 3, THE PROGRAM WILL TRANSITION FOR DELIVERY WITHIN LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS. DISTRICT EDUCATORS THAT GRADUATE FROM T3/PD WILL DELIVER THREE 5-DAY SESSIONS WITH CLC ASSISTANCE. CLC WILL LEVERAGE BWET FUNDING AND PROGRAM EFFECTIVENESS DATA TO IDENTIFY AND ACQUIRE FUNDING FROM NEW SOURCES TO SUSTAIN THE PROGRAM AFTER THE BWET GRANT PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE.

CORAL REEFS ARE EXPERIENCING ALARMING LOSSES IN LIVE CORAL COVER WORLDWIDE. THE OBSERVED DECLINES IN CORAL COVER EMPHASIZE THE NEED FOR MORE EFFECTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. OVER THE PAST TEN YEARS, CORAL-REEF HABITATS IN PAPAH NAUMOKU KEA MARINE NATIONAL MONUMENT
(PMNM) ENCOMPASSING THE NORTHWESTERN HAWAIIAN ISLANDS (NWHI) HAVE BEEN SEVERELY DAMAGED BY CORAL BLEACHING EVENTS, HURRICANES AND INVASIVE SPECIES. PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THESE ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY VALUABLE HABITATS REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE LINKAGES BETWEEN REEF STRUCTURE AND ORGANISMAL BIODIVERSITY. A LACK OF UNDERSTANDING OF HOW HABITAT DYNAMICS INFLUENCE BIODIVERSITY ACROSS A MULTITUDE OF SPATIAL SCALES CREATES A BARRIER TO EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT. THERE IS A NEED TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC STRUCTURAL CHARACTERISTICS OF REEFS THAT INFLUENCE THE ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY OF ORGANISMS FROM THE SPATIAL SCALES OF INDIVIDUAL CORAL COLONIES TO ENTIRE ATOLLS. ADVANCEMENTS IN TECHNOLOGIES NOW ENABLE MORE FREQUENT AND EFFICIENT MONITORING
OF CORAL-REEFS, AND THE ABILITY TO USE THESE TECHNOLOGIES TO IDENTIFY VULNERABLE AND RESILIENT REEFS IS CRUCIAL FOR MANAGEMENT SUCCESS1,5. TWO EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES THAT CAN BE LEVERAGED TO MEET THIS
NEED ARE STRUCTURE-FROM-MOTION (SFM) PHOTOGRAMMETRY AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) ANALYSIS.

MESOPHOTIC REEF ECOSYSTEMS (MRES), COMMONLY FOUND BETWEEN 30 AND 150 M, ARE TROPICAL AND SUB-TROPICAL LIGHT-DEPENDENT REEF COMMUNITIES. IN THE U.S., REEFS PROVIDE NUMEROUS ECOSYSTEM SERVICES VALUED AT US$3.4 BILLION PER YEAR, AND MRES CONTRIBUTE AS ESSENTIAL HABITATS FOR ECONOMICALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT FISH SPECIES TO BREED, SPAWN, FEED AND MATURE.2 NOAA NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES (NMS) MANAGE MANY OF THESE MRE REGIONS IN THE U.S. FOR EXAMPLE, THE FLOWER GARDEN BANKS (FGB) NMS IN THE NORTHWESTERN GULF OF MEXICO, WAS FOUNDED IN 1992 AND EXPANDED IN 2021, AND IS THE ONLY NMS IN THE GULF. THERE ARE ABUNDANT MRES IN FGB THAT REQUIRE BASELINE KNOWLEDGE TO ENABLE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND DIRECT FUTURE RESEARCH EFFORTS. LONG-TERM ENVIRONMENTAL DATA HAS NOT BEEN COLLECTED FOR ANY MRES IN FGB, DESPITE THEIR SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE. THUS, FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH IS URGENTLY NEEDED FOR MRES IN FGB AND THE GULF OF MEXICO.

MARINE DISEASES HAVE THE CAPABILITY TO DECIMATE ENTIRE COMMUNITIES OF LIVING ORGANISMS, UNDOING DECADES OF POPULATION GROWTH IN A FRACTION OF THE TIME. WHILE CONSIDERABLE FOCUS HAS BEEN ON THE ROLE OF THE ENVIRONMENT IN DETERMINING DISEASE OUTCOMES, HOST POPULATIONS IN
DIFFERENT LOCATIONS EXPERIENCE DISTINCT ENVIRONMENTAL PRESSURES AND, AS A RESULT, VARY IN DISEASE SUSCEPTIBILITY (DUBOIS ET AL. 2022). PATHOGENS LIKELY ALSO VARY IN IMPORTANT TRAITS, HOWEVER THIS VARIATION AND ITS IMPACT ON HOST INFECTION ARE OFTEN POORLY CHARACTERIZED FOR MARINE DISEASES. THIS RESEARCH PROPOSAL AIMS TO ASSESS HOW PATHOGEN VARIATION IMPACTS DISEASE DYNAMICS OF THE VITAL MARINE FOUNDATION SPECIES ZOSTERA MARINA, A SEAGRASS FOUND THROUGHOUT THE GREATER FARALLONES NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (GFNMS) AND WITHIN THE ESTUARY OF TOMALES BAY (TB).

WOODEN SHIPWRECKS REPRESENT A SUBSTANTIAL HISTORICAL AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCE DOCUMENTING HUMAN MOVEMENT, WAR, AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES. THEY LIE SUBMERGED IN WATERS AROUND THE NATION. THESE MARKERS OF HISTORY ARE INCREASINGLY THREATENED BY CHANGING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS. ABIOTIC ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES (E.G., WARMING SEAS AND OCEAN ACIDIFICATION) AND ASSOCIATED BIOTIC FLUCTUATIONS (E.G., SPECIES RANGES) INCREASINGLY IMPACT MORE SITES THROUGH DEGRADATION AND DETERIORATION (SPALDING 2011; WRIGHT 2016). THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO EXAMINE THE EFFECT OF SELECT ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC CHANGES ON WOODEN SHIPWRECK DEGRADATION TO AID IN LONG-TERM IN SITU PRESERVATION, ALLOWING FUTURE GENERATIONS TO LEARN OUR SHARED WORLD HISTORY.

ALTHOUGH THE DEEP SEA IS THE LARGEST ECOSYSTEM ON EARTH, IT IS UNDERSTUDIED DUE TO THE EXPENSE AND CHALLENGE OF SCIENTIFIC EXPLORATION. CORALS, CNIDARIANS THAT SECRETE EITHER CALCIUM CARBONATE SKELETONS/SCLERITES OR A PROTEINACEOUS AXIS (CAIRNS 2007), CAN FORM BIODIVERSE AND IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS IN THE DEEP SEA. DEEP-SEA CORALS, ALSO CALLED COLD-WATER CORALS, ARE AZOOXANTHELLATE COUNTERPARTS TO SHALLOW SPECIES FOUND BELOW 50M (HOURIGAN ET AL. 2017). UNLIKE ZOOXANTHELLATE SHALLOW-WATER CORALS, DEEP-SEA CORALS ARE ENTIRELY SUSPENSION FEEDERS THAT GROW ON HARD SUBSTRATA IN AREAS WHERE HIGH FLOW ALLOWS FOR SUFFICIENT FOOD AVAILABILITY. SEVERAL DEEP-SEA CORAL SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED ECOSYSTEM ENGINEERS (JONES ET AL. 1994) BECAUSE THEY FORM REEF FRAMEWORKS THAT CAN BE USED AS HABITAT BY OTHER ORGANISMS. SOME CAN BUILD BIOHERMS OUT OF THEIR CALCIUM CARBONATE SKELETONS THAT RISE ABOVE THE SEAFLOOR, CREATING THREE-DIMENSIONAL MOUNDS THAT ALTER HYDRODYNAMIC FLOW AND SEDIMENTATION RATES (SOETAER

THE FLOWER GARDEN BANKS NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (FGBNMS) IS HOME TO 17 REEFS WITH OVER ~50% LIVING CORAL COVER. THE MASSIVE STARLET SIDERASTREA SIDEREA CORAL IS ONE OF THE MOST STUDIED SPECIES WITHIN THE SANCTUARY. LIKE MOST STONY CORALS, S. SIDEREA  13C RECORDS ARE AN EXCELLENT PROXY FOR MEASURING THE ADDITION OF CO2 TO SEAWATER, AND THEREFORE CAN BE USED TO ANALYZE THE IMPACT OF FOSSIL FUEL BURNING ON OCEAN CONDITIONS. HOWEVER, BECAUSE CORALS ACTIVELY UPTAKE CARBON FOR BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES, THEIR  13C RECORDS ARE NOT IN EQUILIBRIUM WITH THE DISSOLVED INORGANIC CARBON (DIC) IN SEAWATER. THEREFORE, IF WE WANT TO UTILIZE CORAL  13C RECORDS TO INTERPRET SEAWATER CO2 CONCENTRATION, WE MUST UNDERSTAND HOW "VITAL EFFECTS" (THE INFLUENCE OF BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES ON THE GEOCHEMICAL RECORD) INFLUENCE THE CORAL  13C/ SEAWATER DIC RELATIONSHIP. THE SECOND PORTION OF MY PROJECT AIMS TO INVESTIGATE IF THE 2022 CORAL DISEASE EVENT IN THE FGBNMS WAS RECORDED WITHIN THE S. SIDEREA

BLUE CARBON ECOSYSTEMS SUCH AS SALT MARSHES AND MANGROVES ACCOUNT FOR APPROXIMATELY 50% OF THE ORGANIC CARBON ACTIVELY ACCUMULATING IN THE WORLD'S OCEAN, AND THEREFORE PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN NATURAL MARINE SEQUESTRATION OF ATMOSPHERIC CO2. RECENT RESEARCH HAS ESTIMATED SEAGRASS BEDS MAY OUTPACE OTHER BLUE CARBON HABITATS AS SITES OF NATURAL CO2 SEQUESTRATION,2 BUT FEW STUDIES HAVE BEEN ABLE TO QUANTIFY THE CARBON BURIAL CAPACITY OF SEAGRASS BEDS WITH HIGH ACCURACY. RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE UNDERLYING CARBON BURIAL MECHANISMS OF SEAGRASS MEADOWS, AND ROBUST DATA ON BLUE CARBON STORAGE IN SEAGRASS IS LACKING COMPARED TO THE EXTENT OF RESEARCH AVAILABLE ON SALT MARSHES AND MANGROVES. THOUGH RECENT STUDIES SUGGEST SEAGRASS BEDS MAY BE THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT CARBON SINK ON EARTH, CORRESPONDING TO 10 TO 40% OF THE OCEAN'S ANNUAL ORGANIC CARBON BURIAL ALONE, MOST ASSESSMENTS OF THE GLOBAL SEAGRASS CARBON STOCK RELY ON MEASURING CARBON IN SURFACE SEDIMENTS AND GENERALIZIN

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO: ENGAGING K-12 STUDENTS IN AUTHENTIC WATERSHED EXPERIENCES, SCIENCE AND STEWARDSHIP: RECONNECTING TO THE LAND AT EARTH HEART FARMS WILL OFFER TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WITH LONG-TERM CLASSROOM-INTEGRATED MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS FROM PORT CLINTON, TOLEDO, SANDUSKY AND NORWALK, OHIO FOCUSING ON THE CONSERVATION EFFORTS AT EARTH HEART FARMS (EHF). EHF IS AN 80-ACRE PROPERTY THAT HAS BEEN IN CONSERVATION FOR 30 YEARS AND IS A SITE FOR BIRDING WITH A HIGH LEVEL OF BIODIVERSITY. THE OWNER IS WORKING WITH MANY PARTNERS TO MAKE EHF A DESTINATION FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS TO CONNECT WITH THE LAND AND LEARN ABOUT THE SCIENCE OF NUTRIENT RUNOFF AND HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) ON LAKE ERIE. TEACHERS WILL RECEIVE SUMMER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND SUPPORT THROUGHOUT THE SCHOOL YEAR IN THE FORM OF SCHOOL VISITS, WEB MEETINGS AND WEBINARS BY SCIENTISTS. STUDENTS WILL VISIT EHFS TWO TIMES DURING THE S

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM PAUL SMITH'S COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES: YOUTH FOR CLIMATE AND WATER ACTION: MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR RURAL SCHOOLS IN THE LAKE ONTARIO WILL GUIDE STUDENTS AND SUPPORT TEACHERS TO EXPLORE AND COMPARE CLIMATE CHANGE PRESSURES THAT ARE DEGRADING WATER RESOURCES IN GREAT LAKES COMMUNITIES AND THE INEQUITIES THAT EXIST AROUND THESE THREATS IN RURAL AREAS IN THE ADIRONDACKS AND THE FINGER LAKES. THE MWEE WILL FOCUS ON DEEP LEARNING WITH A SMALL COHORT OF SIX SCHOOL DISTRICTS, PARTNER HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS, AND APPROXIMATELY 200 STUDENTS IN RURAL, LOW-INCOME, SOCIO-ECONOMICALLY DISTRESSED COMMUNITIES IN THE LAKE ONTARIO WATERSHED. IT WILL HELP STUDENTS AND TEACHERS DEVELOP MEANINGFUL PERSONAL CONNECTIONS TO CLIMATE IMPACTS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND HELP PREPARE THEM TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THEIR WATERSHED. IT WILL SUPPORT STUDENT IMPLEMENTATION OF SIX PLACE-BASED, EQUITY-FOCUSED CLIMATE AND WATER ACTION PROJECTS THAT INCREASE CLIMATE RES

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM EASTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY/SOUTHEAST MICHIGAN STEWARDSHIP COALITION: COALITION CONNECTIONS: BUILDING WATERSHED AND CLIMATE LITERACY THROUGH PLACE-BASED EXPLORATIONS WILL EXPAND UPON A FOUNDATION OF WORK IN PLACE-BASED STEWARDSHIP EDUCATION FOCUSED ON WATERSHED ISSUES TO: ORGANIZE A COMPELLING, SEMIS COALITION PROFESSIONAL LEARNING SEQUENCE FOR THE SUMMERS OF 2023 AND 2024 AND THE 2023-25 SCHOOL YEARS THAT SUPPORTS MWEES WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY RESILIENCE IN THE SCHOOL AND SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOOD ENVIRONMENT; SUPPORT 15 ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL TEACHERS EACH YEAR (2-4 OF WHICH ARE COLLABORATORS ACROSS COMMUNITIES/WATERSHEDS), THEIR STUDENTS, AND THEIR COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING MWEES LINKED TO COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, HIGHLIGHTING CLIMATE EFFECTS ON STORMWATER AND WATERSHED HEALTH; AND USE SEMIS PROFESSIONAL LEARNING AND MWEES TO SUPPORT TEACHER AND STUDENT CIVIC ENGAGEMENT TOWARD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS, DEMONST

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM CENTRAL MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY: BUILDING FLOOD RESILIENCE BY CONNECTING STUDENTS TO THEIR WATERSHED WILL ENGAGE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN CENTRAL MICHIGAN TO BROADEN AWARENESS OF FLOOD RISK AND CLIMATE CHANGE AND EMPOWER THEM TO EVALUATE AND IMPLEMENT FLOOD RESILIENCE SOLUTIONS IN THEIR WATERSHED. IT WILL DEVELOP A SET OF MODULES AS PART OF A MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE (MWEE) THAT WILL GIVE STUDENTS EXPERIENCE COLLECTING AND ANALYZING CLIMATE AND FLOOD DATA, USE SIMULATIONS TO EXPLORE FLOOD RISK, AND VISIT NATURAL INFRASTRUCTURE LOCATIONS THAT HELP CONTRIBUTE TO FLOOD RESILIENCE IN THEIR WATERSHEDS. STUDENTS WILL ALSO DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECTS THAT WILL DEMONSTRATE TO THE PUBLIC THE FLOOD RISK CONCEPTS THEY LEARN AND THE ROLE OF FLOOD RESILIENCE SOLUTIONS. THESE PROJECTS WILL FORM THE BASIS OF A DISTRIBUTED MUSEUM OF FLOOD RESILIENCE, WITH EXHIBITS DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED THAT RESIDENTS CAN PHYSICALLY VISIT. EXHIBI

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM THE BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF CHICAGO: "ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY FOR ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE" WILL LAUNCH A NEW PROGRAM TO BUILD SCHOOL-WIDE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY THROUGH CORE SCIENCE INSTRUCTION (BIOLOGY, CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS) SO THAT STUDENTS, TEACHERS, ADMINISTRATORS, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS GAIN THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND CONFIDENCE TO COLLECTIVELY TAKE ACTION TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL ZONE, AND SCHOOL COMMUNITIES ARE SUPPORTED IN UNDERSTANDING AND INVESTIGATING SCIENTIFIC SOLUTIONS WHICH BUILD RESILIENCE TO EXTREME WEATHER AND CLIMATE CHANGE. EL FOR EJ HAS THE POTENTIAL TO SERVE AS A MODEL FOR ALL CPS HIGH SCHOOLS, PILOTING AN APPROACH THAT LINKS STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM TO ON THE GROUND IMPROVEMENTS, TO "PREPARING STUDENTS FOR SUCCESS IN CIVIC LIFE" (A KEY TENET OF CPS' MISSION). THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE: SCHOOL-WIDE ENGAGEMENT TO BUILD ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY THROUGH PLACE-BASED

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY: SUPPORTING DATA-CENTERED 3-P STUDENT LEARNING THROUGH TEACHER- AND STUDENT-SCAFFOLDED EXPERIENCES USING MIWATERNET STREAM MONITORING WILL CONTINUE STRENGTHENING A CONNECTION WITH >110 STUDENTS FROM FIVE HIGH SCHOOLS IN THE EASTERN UPPER PENINSULA (MI) TO THEIR GREAT LAKES WATERSHED USING LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY'S CENTER FOR FRESHWATER RESEARCH AND EDUCATION MIWATERNET INITIATIVE. THIS PROJECT EXPANDS ON A PREVIOUS PROJECT, INTEGRATING FRESHWATER AND DATA LITERACY AMONG HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THROUGH REAL-TIME STREAM MONITORING WITH MIWATERNET BY ENHANCING APPROACHES USED TO DEVELOP DATA SCIENCE LITERACY FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS THROUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, HANDS-ON FIELD WORK ACCOMPANIED BY DATA WORKSHOPS, INSTRUCTIONAL COACHING FOR TEACHERS, AND PROFESSIONAL MENTORS TO CONNECT STUDENTS TO STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS. AS A RESULT, TEACHERS WILL INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND CONFIDENCE TO LEAD STUDENTS TO USE REAL-TIME WATER MONI

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM THE BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN SYSTEM: RIVERS2LAKE: ACTIVATING A COMMUNITY OF LAKE SUPERIOR EDUCATORS WILL FORMALLY TRACK AND SUPPORT UP TO 105 RIVERS2LAKE ALUMNI TEACHERS IN A MENTOR NETWORK AND EXPANDS CAPACITY FOR MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN WISCONSIN'S LAKE SUPERIOR BASIN. IT BRINGS TOGETHER A COMMUNITY OF PARTNERS INCLUDING SUPERIOR RIVERS WATERSHED ASSOCIATION, NORTHLAND COLLEGE, AND GREAT LAKES INDIAN FISH & WILDLIFE COMMISSION TO SUPPORT THIS EXPANSION. IT INTEGRATES STUDENT-CENTERED EDUCATION MATERIALS FROM THE GREAT LAKES INDIAN FISH & WILDLIFE COMMISSION (GLIFWC) WITH CLASSROOMS-ENSURING THAT PARTICIPATING TEACHERS AND STUDENTS CONTINUE TO ENGAGE IN PLACE-BASED AND EXPERIENTIAL TEACHING AND LEARNING LONG-TERM. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, RIVERS2LAKE EDUCATION STAFF AT THE RESERVE AND SUPERIOR RIVERS WATERSHED ASSOCIATION WITH AN EDUCATIONAL CONSULTANT BASED A NORTHLAND COLLEGE WILL ACTIV

DURING THE NEXT FIVE YEARS, THE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY FOUNDATION IS SETTING AMBITIOUS METRICS IN THE FOLLOWING FIVE PROJECT AREAS: STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT, SUSTAINABLE ENJOYMENT AND VISITATION, EDUCATION, CULTURE AND MARITIME HERITAGE, AND SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY. THESE PROJECT AREAS WILL SPAN ACROSS THE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY SYSTEM AND WILL WORK TOWARDS INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS OF AND INVESTMENT IN THESE NATIONAL TREASURES THROUGH EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND CONVERSATION PROGRAMMING. THESE PROJECT AREAS TIE IN DIRECTLY TO OFFICE OF NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES' FIVE-YEAR PLAN FOR ADVANCING THE PROTECTION OF THE SANCTUARY SYSTEM. ALL COOPERATIVE PROJECTS DEMONSTRATE THE FOUNDATION'S COMMITMENT TO AND VISION FOR THESE AMAZING PLACES BOTH IMMEDIATELY AND LONG-TERM.

CORAL DISEASE OUTBREAKS HAVE BECOME MAYOR DRIVERS OF WORLDWIDE CORAL COVER DECLINE. SUCH DRIVERS ARE HIGHLY ASSOCIATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE FACTORS SUCH AS INCREASE IN SEA-SURFACE TEMPERATURE AND OCEAN ACIDIFICATION, COMBINED WITH ANTHROPOGENIC FACTORS SUCH AS LAND-DWELLING SOURCES OF POLLUTION. THE STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS DISEASE WAS SPOTTED FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 2014 ALONG THE FLORIDA KEYS REEF TRACT AND SINCE THEN IT HAS SPREAD ACROSS THE CARIBBEAN.

OUR PROJECT GOAL IS TO ADAPT OUR CHANGING CURRENTS: SUMMIT TO SEA TRIBAL YOUTH WATER EDUCATION CURRICULUM TO A CLASSROOM FORMAT THAT IS ACCESSIBLE TO TEACHERS AND EDUCATORS. WE ARE SEEKING TO BRIDGE THE EXISTING PROGRAM PARTNERS TO SUPPORT EXPANDED CONNECTION TO TRIBAL STUDENTS IN THEIR LOCAL SCHOOLS AND EXPAND THE OPPORTUNITY FOR CLASSROOM AND INTEGRATED MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES THAT INCLUDE A CULTURAL RELEVANT LENS ON TRIBAL WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND INDIGENOUS ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE.

THIS STUDY WILL USE NOVEL METHODS TO SEPARATE AND QUANTIFY FISH CHORUSES, IN ORDER TO GENERATE CHORUS MAGNITUDE METRICS TO MONITOR NMS FISHES.  THESE METRICS CAN BE USED IN NOAA'S INTEGRATED ECOSYSTEM ASSESSMENT AND INFORM SANCTUARY CONDITION REPORTS, HOOK AND LINE METHODS, WITH COARSE TEMPORAL RESOLUTION.    STUDYING IMPACTS OF MARINE HEAT WAVES ON FISH WILL ALLOW US TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW CLIMATE CHANGE WILL IMPACT FISH MONITORING, BETTER UNDERSTAND FISH BEHAVIOR, PROTECT VULNERABLE NMS SPECIES, AND SUPPORT FISHING/CULTURAL TRADITIONS OF COASTAL INDIGENOUS PEOPLES.

OUR PROGRAM WILL OFFER HIGH QUALITY TEACHER EDUCATION, PRESENTATIONS, AND FIELD EXPERIENCES THAT WILL HIGHLIGHT THE PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH CLIMATE CHANGE AND SEA-LEVEL RISE IN AFFECTED COMMUNITIES. THE TEACHERS THAT ARE SUPPORTING THIS PROJECT EXPERIENCED RECORD SETTING HEAT WAVES, FISH KILLS, RECORD DROUGHTS AND FLOODS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES DURING 2021, MAKING THIS PROGRAM ESPECIALLY RELEVANT.  HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN 8 SCHOOL DISTRICTS ALONG THE SOUTHWEST AND OLYMPIC COAST OF WASHINGTON STATE WILL BE PROVIDED WITH OUTDOOR INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCES AND A TEACHER WORKSHOP IN THEIR WATERSHEDS. WITHIN THIS TARGET AREA THERE ARE A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF HISPANIC AND NATIVE AMERICAN STUDENTS. GRAYS HARBOR COUNTY AND THE WESTERN PORTION OF JEFFERSON COUNTY ARE SOME OF THE POOREST REGIONS OF THE STATE. BASED ON THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH'S ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH DISPARITIES MAP, THESE AREAS RANK VERY HIGH ON THE RISK SCALE FOR CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY, IN SINGLE P

MORE THAN 60% OF ALL CORAL REEFS IN U.S. WATERS ARE FOUND WITHIN THE HAWAIIAN ARCHIPELAGO AND IT IS ESTIMATED THE CORALS GENERATE ~800 MILLION USD ANNUALLY THROUGH TOURISM. PMNM ALONE IS ESTIMATED TO HOUSE OVER 7,000 SPECIES OF MARINE LIFE WITH SHALLOW WATER, STONY CORALS ACCOUNTING FOR ALMOST 60 OF THOSE SPECIES. NMSAS IS ESTIMATED TO HAVE OVER 340 SPECIES OF CORALS WITH ~2,700 KNOWN SPECIES RELYING ON THIS HABITAT WHICH INCLUDES 32 OF THE 33 ANIMAL PHYLA. AN EMERGING THREAT OF CONCERN TO THESE ECOSYSTEMS IS PLASTIC POLLUTION, WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR 60-80% OF ALL MARINE DEBRIS AFFECTING ALL ORGANISMS AND HABITATS IN THE OCEAN.

OFFSHORE WIND POWER WILL BE CRUCIAL TO REACH SUSTAINABLE ENERGY GOALS AND IS RAPIDLY EXPANDING, WITH NEW DEVELOPMENTS PLANNED FOR THE PACIFIC OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF. HOWEVER, SEABIRDS ARE ALREADY THE MOST THREATENED GROUP OF MARINE ANIMALS AND ARE VULNERABLE TO OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. WE CAN FACILITATE BOTH RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT FROM OFFSHORE WIND AND THRIVING SEABIRD POPULATIONS BY CAREFULLY EVALUATING THE IMPACTS OF OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY AND MITIGATING THEM USING COMPENSATORY CONSERVATION ACTIONS ON ADJACENT WATERS AND BREEDING COLONIES. I WILL: 1) QUANTITATIVELY ASSESS THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF PROPOSED PACIFIC WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON SEABIRDS IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT ECOSYSTEM BY INTEGRATING EMPIRICAL DATA ON SEABIRD DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND LIFE HISTORY WITH COLLISION RISK MODELS AND CUTTING-EDGE SEABIRD POPULATION MODELS, AND 2) QUANTITATIVELY IDENTIFY FEASIBLE COMPENSATORY MITIGATION MEASURES TO ADDRESS IMPACTS ON THREATENED POPULATIONS USING PROVEN CONSERVATION TOOLS AND INDUSTRY MEASURES.

CLIMATE-DRIVEN CHANGES ARE RAPIDLY RESTRUCTURING THE GULF OF MAINE (GOM) ECOSYSTEM, RESULTING IN INCREASED TEMPERATURES AND A NUMBER OF RELATED CHANGES IN OCEANOGRAPHY, SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS AND ABUNDANCE AND COMMUNITY STRUCTURE (PERSHING ET AL. 2019). BECAUSE OF THESE ONGOING CHANGES, CLIMATE WAS RECENTLY IDENTIFIED AS A CRITICAL CROSS-CUTTING ISSUE FOR THE MARINE ECOSYSTEM IN STELLWAGEN BANK NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (SBNMS). STELLWAGEN, IN PARTICULAR, IS A SEASONAL HOTSPOT FOR A RANGE OF HIGHLY MIGRATORY SPECIES, INCLUDING THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE AND SEVERAL SEABIRD AND FISH SPECIES, THAT UNDERGO LONG DISTANCE MIGRATIONS TO ACCESS SEASONAL PEAKS OF PRODUCTIVITY IN THE REGION.

KELP FORESTS ARE ONE OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE AND BIODIVERSE MARINE ECOSYSTEMS ON THE PLANET.  IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT SYSTEM (CCS), CANOPY-FORMING KELPS SERVE AS FOUNDATIONAL SPECIES IN THE NEARSHORE ENVIRONMENT, PROVIDING AN ARRAY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT SUPPORT HIGH BIODIVERSITY, COMPLEX FOOD WEBS, AND BENEFIT LOCAL COASTAL COMMUNITIES.1,2 KELP FOREST ECOSYSTEMS ARE FOUND IN ALL FOUR WEST COAST REGION (WCR) NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES (NMSS) THAT ENCOMPASS COASTAL WATERS: OLYMPIC COAST (OCNMS), GREATER FARALLONES (GFNMS), MONTEREY BAY (MBNMS) AND CHANNEL ISLANDS (CINMS), INCLUDING THE PROPOSED CHUMASH HERITAGE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (CHNMS). RECENT YEARS HAVE SEEN UNPRECEDENTED DECLINES OF KELP FOREST CANOPIES IN GFNMS AND MBNMS AND A REPORTED DECREASE IN THE NUTRITIONAL QUALITY OF KELP TISSUE IN MAINLAND WATERS ADJACENT TO CINMS, MAKING THEIR MANAGEMENT AND RESILIENCE A WCR SANCTUARY-WIDE ISSUE. THESE OBSERVATIONS ARE BROADLY LINKED TO INCREASING TEMPERATURE AND BENTHIC CONS

WORLDWIDE, CORAL REEFS ARE SUBJECT TO INCREASED WATER TEMPERATURES AND INCREASED CO2 LEVELS MAKING FOR A LESS HABITABLE ENVIRONMENT FOR MANY CALCIFYING SPECIES. DECLINES IN CORAL RESILIENCE MAKES CORAL-DOMINATED REEFS SUSCEPTIBLE TO INVASIVE SPECIES AND MACROALGAL OVERGROWTH. THIS LEADS TO PHASE SHIFTS FROM CORAL-DOMINATED TO MACROALGAL-DOMINATED REEFS, WITH CONCOMITANT CONSEQUENCES FOR COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND HABITAT COMPLEXITY.

THIS PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE A DISTRICT-WIDE INCREASE IN AUTHENTIC AND LOCALLY RELEVANT SCIENCE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR ALL 5TH GRADE STUDENTS IN EAST WENATCHEE, WASHINGTON LEADING TO STUDENT-LED STEWARDSHIP ACTION TO IMPROVE OUR WATERSHEDS AND RECOVER IMPERILED SALMON. TEACHERS WILL CONFIDENTLY IMPLEMENT MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEACHING THROUGH MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) AND CURRICULUM INTEGRATION TO BETTER SERVE STUDENT POPULATIONS OF ALL LEARNING ABILITIES AND CULTURAL BACKGROUNDS. STUDENTS WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE ABOUT LOCAL SALMON AND WATERSHED PHENOMENA, EFFECTS OF HUMAN IMPACTS, REGIONAL INDIGENOUS CULTURE, KNOWLEDGE, AND HISTORY, AND PARTICIPATE IN OUTDOOR INVESTIGATIONS OF LOCAL STREAMS AND THEIR OWN SCHOOLYARDS LEADING TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF STEWARDSHIP ACTIONS ADDRESSING ISSUES IDENTIFIED THROUGHOUT THE SCHOOL YEAR. THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (PD) AND PARTNERSHIPS WITH A DIVERSE RANGE OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS FOR 5TH GRADE TE

FROM SALMON HEROES TO ORCA ACTIONS WILL WORK WITH HIGHLINE SCHOOL DISTRICT STAFF TO INTEGRATE ESC'S SALMON CURRICULUM WITH NOAA'S SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALE CURRICULUM INTO A UNIT FOR ALL HIGHLINE 8TH GRADERS. TEACHERS WILL ATTEND A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP SERIES TO GAIN CONFIDENCE IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE MWEE AND WILL BE ABLE TO GUIDE THEIR STUDENTS FROM THE INITIAL ISSUE DEFINITION THROUGH STUDENT-LED ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECTS ON SCHOOL CAMPUSES. TRAINING (27-33 HOURS, INCLUDING 13-22 HOURS SPENT OUTSIDE) WILL CONSIST OF THE FOLLOWING: O TWO FULL-DAY TEACHER TRAINING WORKSHOPS IN AUGUST; O MONTHLY EVENING WORKSHOPS (SEPTEMBER-NOVEMBER) LED BY COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATION PARTNERS BASILICA BIO AND SEA POTENTIAL; O DIRECT ON-SITE ASSISTANCE FOR BOTH FIELD-BASED EXPERIENCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECTS FROM ESC STAFF AND NATURALISTS.  PROJECT OBJECTIVES: 1) INCREASE TEACHER KNOWLEDGE OF THE IMPORTANCE OF SALMON AND ORCAS TO OUR LOCAL COMMUNITY AND ECOSYSTEM, AS

NSEA'S PLACE-BASED WATERSHED SCIENCE PROGRAM STUDENTS FOR SALMON (SFS) IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN WHATCOM COUNTY FOURTH GRADE CLASSROOMS IN PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND TRIBAL SCHOOLS AND NSEA STAFF. OVER THE COURSE OF 5-6 WEEKS EACH CLASSROOM IS PROVIDED BOTH CLASSROOM AND OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES FACILITATED BY SEA STAFF IN TANDEM WITH TEACHERS LEADING 12 OUTDOOR LESSONS FROM A FOUR-UNIT CURRICULUM. RECENTLY THE CURRICULUM HAS BEEN UPDATED BY A GROUP OF WESTERN WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY STUDENTS TO BETTER ALIGN WITH CLIMATE SCIENCE STANDARDS, INCORPORATE SOCIAL JUSTICE AND INDIGENOUS SCIENCE, AND TO FURTHER CONNECT LOCAL RESOURCES. NSEA STAFF IS ANXIOUS TO PILOT THE NEW CURRICULUM AND HAVE IDENTIFIED THE NOAA B-WET GRANT AS AN IDEAL OPPORTUNITY TO SET TEACHERS UP FOR SUCCESS BY PROVIDING IN-DEPTH TRAINING, ULTIMATELY MAXIMIZING THE EXPERIENCE FOR STUDENTS. THEREFORE, THE PROPOSED 6-MONTH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SERIES (~40 HOURS/10 SESSIONS) LED BY NSEA STAFF AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON

THE SANTA CLARA COUNTY OFFICE OF EDUCATION (SCCOE) PROPOSES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A THREE-YEAR PROFESSIONAL LEARNING MODEL - STUDENT AND PROFESSIONAL LEARNING TO ADVANCE STEWARDSHIP FOR H2O! (SPLASH!) IN SOUTH SANTA CLARA COUNTY FOR MIDDLE SCHOOL (SIXTH, SEVENTH, AND EIGHTH GRADE) TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN TWO SCHOOL DISTRICTS WITH ONE COLLABORATIVE PARTNER. A COHORT OF 20 LEAD TEACHERS WILL PROVIDE 600 STUDENTS PER YEAR WITH HANDS-ON MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES IN THE CLASSROOM AND FIELD ALIGNED WITH NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS (NGSS) AND ENVIRONMENTAL PRINCIPLES AND CONCEPTS (EP&CS). THIS PROJECT WILL SYSTEMATICALLY REACH ALL MIDDLE SCHOOL TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN THE GILROY AND MORGAN HILL DISTRICTS OVER THE THREE YEARS OF THE PROJECT.

STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN THIS PROJECT WILL JOIN A TEAM OF FEDERAL AND ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS AND BECOME CRUCIAL SCIENTIFIC PARTNERS IN AN EFFORT TO SOLVE A MYSTERY THAT THREATENS SALMON POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA'S CENTRAL VALLEY.

THE SALINAS UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT (SUHSD) COMMUNITY SCIENCE & OUTDOOR LEARNING COLLABORATIVE IS A MULTI-YEAR PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE DISTRICT'S EDUCATIONAL SERVICES TEAM, BIRD SCHOOL PROJECT (BSP), AND PACIFIC GROVE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY (PG MUSEUM) TO CREATE AND IMPLEMENT ANNUAL MWEES FOR TEACHERS AND LOCAL OUTDOOR EDUCATION INSTRUCTORS THAT LINK TO ONGOING OUTDOOR LEARNING AND YOUTH-FOCUSED COMMUNITY SCIENCE PROJECTS FOR STUDENTS IN SUHSD. TEACHER LEADERS WILL LEARN ALONGSIDE LOCAL OUTDOOR EDUCATORS AND LEADERS FROM COMMUNITY-BASED PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO INTEGRATE LONG-TERM OUTDOOR EXPLORATION AND MONITORING OF THE SALINAS RIVER WATERSHED AND THE MONTEREY BAY NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY INTO THEIR CURRICULA.

THE EVERY CLASSROOM A GREEN CLASSROOM PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE ALL ELEMENTS OF A MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE (MWEE) TO INCREASE THE SCIENTIFIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY OF TEACHERS AND STUDENTS BY INTEGRATING CLASSROOM CURRICULUM WITH OUTDOOR LEARNING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES. FOR THE 3-YEAR GRANT PERIOD AT LEAST 133 TEACHERS AND 6,175 STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE. THE TOTAL PROJECT COST PER STUDENT/TEACHER IS $72.82, $47.56 FEDERAL FUNDING AND $25.26 LOCAL FUNDING. IN YEAR 3 OF THIS PROJECT ALL TEACHERS THROUGHOUT SANTA CRUZ COUNTY WILL BE INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE EVERY CLASSROOM A GREEN CLASSROOM CHALLENGE. THE NUMBER OF TEACHER AND STUDENT PARTICIPANTS WILL BE TRACKED TO DEMONSTRATE INCLUSION OF A MUCH LARGER NUMBER.

ONE OF VENTANA WILDLIFE SOCIETY'S STRATEGIC GOALS IS TO INSTILL A CONSERVATION ETHIC AND INSPIRE YOUTH TO ACT FULLY BY INTEGRATING INNOVATIVE SCIENTIFIC AND ECOLOGICAL EDUCATION. FOR THIS PROJECT WE WILL DO THAT BY PROVIDING MWEE PROFESSIONAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR 288 ALTERNATIVE EDUCATION TEACHERS.

SAVE THE WHALES IS PROPOSING TO PARTNER WITH THREE TITLE 1 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS TO PROVIDE EXTRACURRICULAR SCIENCE EXPERIENCES FOR APPROXIMATELY 320 CHILDREN. THE PROPOSED PROGRAM FOCUSES ON CULTURALLY DIVERSE, UNDERSERVED CHILDREN IN SOUTHERN MONTEREY COUNTY. SOUTH COUNTY CHILDREN ARE PROVIDED FEWER EXTRACURRICULAR EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THAN CHILDREN IN OTHER PARTS OF THE COUNTY, DUE TO THEIR GEOGRAPHIC REMOTENESS. THIS REMOTENESS, COUPLED WITH THE ADDED CHALLENGES OF COVID-19, HAS MADE THE EDUCATIONAL SITUATION FOR CHILDREN IN SOUTH COUNTY ESPECIALLY DIFFICULT.

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM THE BOARD OF EDUCATION OF THE CITY OF CHICAGO: CALUMET IN MY BACKYARD (CIMBY) CIMBY-BUILDING STUDENT AND TEACHER LEADERSHIP WILL: 1) BUILD ON PRIOR SUCCESS IN EXPANDING ACROSS THE SOUTH SIDE OF CHICAGO TO HOST A STUDENT LEADERSHIP PROGRAM (SLP), STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF CHICAGO PUBLIC SCHOOL (CPS) HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN FACILITATING MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) FOR THEIR PEERS; AND 2) HOST A TEACHER PROFESSIONAL LEARNING COMMUNITY (PLC), SO THAT CPS SCIENCE TEACHERS HAVE THE SPACE AND RESOURCES NEEDED TO LEAD SUSTAINED CLASSROOM-INTEGRATED INQUIRY TO ACTION PROJECTS CENTERED IN STUDENTS' IDENTITIES AND COMMUNITIES.

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM FRIENDS OF REINSTEIN NATURE PRESERVE INC: NIAGARA RIVER/LAKE ERIE (NRLE) CLASSROOMS WILL ENGAGE 10 TEACHERS AND 220 STUDENTS IN GRADES 4-12 IN MULTIPLE MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) THAT EXPLORE THE NIAGARA RIVER/LAKE ERIE (NRLE) WATERSHED. TEACHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN EXTENSIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, INCLUDING A MWEE ACADEMY, TO BECOME FAMILIAR WITH THE MWEE FRAMEWORK AND INCREASE THEIR UNDERSTANDING AND AWARENESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES WITHIN THE NRLE WATERSHED. THESE TEACHERS WILL FORM A NETWORK OF NRLE CLASSROOMS TO ENCOURAGE PEER-TO-PEER CONVERSATIONS BETWEEN TEACHERS AND STUDENTS. REINSTEIN WOODS STAFF WILL PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE SUPPORT FOR NRLE CLASSROOMS DURING THE 2022-2023 SCHOOL YEAR TO INCREASE TEACHER CONFIDENCE IN LEADING MWEES. THE TEACHERS WILL THEN BE ABLE TO ENGAGE FUTURE STUDENTS IN ANNUAL MWEES WITH LIMITED OUTSIDE SUPPORT THROUGHOUT THE 2022-2023 SCHOOL YEAR, STUDENTS WILL ENGAGE IN MULTIPLE MWEES, INCLUDING THE &QU

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM MID-MICHIGAN ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION COUNCIL: MID-MICHIGAN WATERSHED CONNECTIONS WILL PROVIDE AN EXTENSIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM FOR TEACHERS IN GRADES 6-9. ENGAGEMENT OF THEIR STUDENTS IN WATERSHED INVESTIGATIONS IS KEY TO IMPROVING COMMUNITY UNDERSTANDING WAYS OF PROTECTING THEM. TEACHERS AND STUDENTS OF TRADITIONALLY UNDERSERVED URBAN (I.E., LANSING SCHOOL DISTRICT) AND RURAL POPULATIONS (INGHAM, EATON, AND CLINTON COUNTIES) ARE THE TARGET. THE TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT INCLUDES FIELD EXPERIENCES SUCH AS HANDS-ON RIVER TESTING, LAKE LIMNOLOGY INVESTIGATIONS, TOURS OF BOTH URBAN STORM WATER AND RURAL WATERSHED PROJECTS, AND FIELD WORK RELATED TO ALL PARTS OF THE WATER CYCLE WITHIN THE WATERSHED. ADDITIONALLY, TEACHER-TRAINING WORKSHOPS WILL EXPLORE MANY ASPECTS OF WATERSHEDS AND SPECIFIC RELATED TEACHING STRATEGIES. TEACHERS WILL GO THROUGH A COMPLETE PROJECT WET TRAINING, ALONG WITH EXPERIENCING A VARIETY OF NOAA, SEA GRANT, AND OTHER ENVIRONMENT

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM UPSTATE FRESHWATER INSTITUTE (UFI): LAKE ONTARIO, ONEIDA, ONONDAGA PROGRAM (LOOOP) WILL BUILD ON AND EXPAND THE SCALE AND SCOPE OF UFIS RECENTLY FUNDED NEW YORK GREAT LAKES BASIN SMALL GRANTS PROGRAM GRANT SUPPORTING TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND STUDENT ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND STEWARDSHIP, WITHIN THE LAKE ONTARIO WATERSHED (U.S.; CENTRAL AND NORTHERN NEW YORK). THE LAKE ONTARIO, ONEIDA, ONONDAGA PROGRAM (LOOOP) AIMS TO PROVIDE HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND RESOURCES TO FACILITATE STUDENT-LED INVESTIGATIONS AND STEWARDSHIP IN THEIR LOCAL WATERSHEDS AND CONNECT STUDENTS WITHIN THE GREATER LAKE ONTARIO BASIN TO ONE ANOTHER. THE LOOOP UTILIZES MULTIPLE DELIVERY METHODS INCLUDING VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING, IN-PERSON WORKSHOPS, AND INTEGRATION OF FIELD EXPERIENCES INTO CLASSROOM PROJECTS TO POTENTIALLY REACH AND CONNECT 45 TEACHERS AND AN ESTIMATED 1,200 STUDENTS; WHILE THE LOOOP HAS THE POTENTIAL TO REACH THIS MANY PEOPLE, WE WILL UTILIZE A FOCUS

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM EASTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY: SCHOOLYARD STEWARDS- PLACE-BASED WATERSHED EXPLORATIONS SUPPORTING COMMUNITY RESILIENCE WILL EXPAND UPON OUR FOUNDATION OF WORK IN PLACE-BASED STEWARDSHIP EDUCATION FOCUSED ON WATERSHED ISSUES TO:  - ORGANIZE A COMPELLING, SOUTHEAST MICHIGAN STEWARDSHIP (SEMIS) COALITION PROFESSIONAL LEARNING SEQUENCE FOR THE SUMMER OF 2022 AND THE 2022-23 SCHOOL YEAR THAT SUPPORTS MWEES WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY RESILIENCE IN THE SCHOOL AND SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOOD ENVIRONMENT;  - SUPPORT 15 TEACHERS (2-4 OF WHICH ARE COLLABORATORS ACROSS COMMUNITIES/WATERSHEDS), THEIR STUDENTS, AND THEIR COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING MWEES LINKED TO COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, HIGHLIGHTING CLIMATE EFFECTS ON STORM WATER AND WATERSHED HEALTH; AND  - USE SEMIS PROFESSIONAL LEARNING AND MWEES TO SUPPORT TEACHER AND STUDENT CIVIC ENGAGEMENT TOWARD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS, DEMONSTRATING THE NEED TO BE EMPOWERED TO PROTECT THEMSELVES,

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM WISCONSIN WILDLIFE FEDERATION: FOX-WOLF RIVER CONNECTIONS- STUDENTS EXPLORE RIPPLE EFFECTS IN THE LAKE MICHIGAN WATERSHED WILL SUPPORT 30 CLASSROOM TEACHERS IN LEADING MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) WITHIN WISCONSIN'S FOX-WOLF WATERSHED, PART OF THE LARGER LAKE MICHIGAN WATERSHED. ACROSS AN ENTIRE SCHOOL YEAR, GRADES PK-12 EDUCATORS FROM 6 SCHOOLS WILL GAIN UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR THE ELEMENTS OF MWEES THROUGH IMMERSIVE FIELD EXPERIENCES, MULTI-DAY WORKSHOPS, COACHING, AND MENTORING OPPORTUNITIES. TEACHERS WILL BROADEN THEIR KNOWLEDGE BASE OF WATERSHED AND CLIMATE SCIENCES, AND THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITY AND LAND USE ON THE HEALTH OF THE RIVERS AND LAKE MICHIGAN ECOSYSTEMS. AT THEIR SCHOOL SITES, DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR, EDUCATORS WILL GAIN SKILLS AND CONFIDENCE TO FACILITATE MWEES ALONGSIDE FIELD "EDVENTURES" COACHES. PROJECT PROPOSED FROM CUYAHOGA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT (SWCD): FIRST RINGS FIRST- MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES FOR TEACHERS AND UNDER-REPRESENTED STUDENTS IN THE CUYAHOGA RIVER AREA OF CONCERN WILL EMPOWER TEACHERS AND STUDENTS ACROSS THE CUYAHOGA RIVER AREA OF CONCERN (CRAOC) TO ADDRESS COMPLEX LOCAL CHALLENGES OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND SOCIAL JUSTICE WITH A COMPREHENSIVE TOOLKIT OF RESOURCES AND SUPPORT SERVICES GROUNDED IN MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES (MWEES). THE PROGRAM WILL INTEGRATE NEW AND EXISTING ELEMENTS TO DELIVER A MENU OF TRAININGS, TOURS, CERTIFICATIONS, CURRICULA, AND TOOLS TO THE FIRST RING SCHOOLS COLLABORATIVE (FRSC), A COLLECTION OF LAKE ERIE BASIN DISTRICTS THAT PRIMARILY SERVE LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES OF COLOR BASED WITHIN CRAOC. CUYAHOGA SWCD, TOGETHER WITH A NETWORK OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS, WILL HELP TEACHERS LEVERAGE THIS TOOLKIT TO REFRAME LOCAL WATERSHED ISSUES IN THE CONTEXT OF COMMUNITY CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH RACE,

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM MUSKEGON AREA INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL DISTRICT: CREATING THE NEXT GENERATION OF GREAT LAKES STEWARDS WILL INCLUDE SCHOOLS IN MUSKEGON, NEWAYGO, OCEANA AND NORTHERN OTTAWA COUNTIES INVOLVING A MINIMUM OF 40 TEACHERS AND 1,500 STUDENTS, WITH A PER TEACHER COST OF $140 AND PER STUDENT COST OF $12 TO SUPPORT MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES). THIS AREA IS CONNECTED TO THE LAKE MICHIGAN WATERSHED AS WELL AS SMALLER ONES, INCLUDING MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED, WHITE LAKE WATERSHED, MUSKEGON LAKE WATERSHED, JUST TO NAME A FEW AND INCLUDES RURAL, SUBURBAN, AND URBAN SCHOOLS. WE ANTICIPATE 12 - 15 SCHOOLS/PROJECTS. SOME SCHOOLS WILL HAVE MULTIPLE PROJECTS AT MULTIPLE GRADE LEVELS THERE ARE THREE PARTS TO THIS WORK. PART A INVOLVES ENGAGING STUDENTS IN MWEE'S, WHICH WILL BE YEAR LONG, CLASSROOM INTEGRATED PROJECTS THAT FOCUS ON STUDENTS WORKING WITH TEACHERS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS ON RESEARCHING, PLANNING, DESIGNING, AND IMPLEMENTING STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS IN THEI

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM FLINT RIVER WATERSHED COALITION: FLINT RIVER ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERS: A SYSTEMIC COMMUNITY APPROACH TO WATER QUALITY SOLUTIONS THROUGH A YOUTH LENS WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE GREAT LAKES STEWARDSHIP INITIATIVE'S DISCOVERING PLACE HUB AT UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN - FLINT AND MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION TO DEVELOP A COMMUNITY-CENTERED APPROACH TO WATERSHED EDUCATION. THE "FLINT RIVER ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERS" PROGRAM WILL WEAVE TOGETHER FLINT RIVER GREEN STUDENT LEADERS, EDUCATORS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS INTO A COHORT THAT WILL GUIDE AND PROVIDE MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES (MWEES) IN BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL SETTINGS THROUGHOUT THE FLINT RIVER WATERSHED.

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM COMMUNITY FOUNDATION FOR NORTHEAST MICHIGAN: PREVENTING MARINE DEBRIS TODAY FOR HEALTHY WATERS TOMORROW WILL APPLY PLACE BASED STEWARDSHIP EDUCATION (PBSE) PRACTICES TO ENGAGE TEACHERS, STUDENTS AND THEIR COMMUNITIES IN MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES). IT WILL ENGAGE MORE THAN 800 K-12 STUDENTS AND 10 TEACHERS FROM LOCAL SCHOOLS IN MWEES WITH A TOTAL FUNDING REQUEST OF $79,856 RESULTING IN AN ESTIMATED $100 COST PER STUDENT ENGAGED IN GREAT LAKES AND WATERSHED STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS. THESE SCHOOLS ARE LOCATED ACROSS EIGHT COUNTIES AND EIGHT LAKE HURON WATERSHEDS AND ARE OFTEN CHARACTERIZED BY ECONOMIC CHALLENGES INCLUDING POVERTY, UNEMPLOYMENT, AND LOW EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT (AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY 2019). ALL PROJECTS SUPPORTED THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL WILL INCLUDE SUSTAINABILITY PLANS AND, AS APPROPRIATE, CONVERSATIONS WITH ADMINISTRATION WILL ENCOURAGE A SYSTEMIC APPROACH TO PBSE PROJECTS.

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM FRIENDS OF THE ROUGE: ROUGE EDUCATION PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE ROUGE EDUCATION PROJECT (REP) WHICH IS AN EXISTING, HIGH QUALITY, SCHOOL-BASED WATER QUALITY MONITORING PROGRAM THAT COMBINES LONG-TERM CLASSROOM-INTEGRATED MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) FOR STUDENTS AND TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THE ROUGE RIVER IS LOCATED WITHIN THE METRO-DETROIT AREA OF MICHIGAN AND IS THE MOST URBANIZED RIVER IN THE STATE COVERING 467 SQUARE MILES AND HOUSING 1.35 MILLION RESIDENTS. THE REP BEGINS WITH RECRUITMENT AND TRAINING OF 3-5 NEW SCHOOLS TO THE PROGRAM, TARGETING TEACHERS WORKING IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. ALL NEW AND MANY RETURNING TEACHERS UNDERGO RIGOROUS TRAINING DURING A SUMMER INSTITUTE ON WATER QUALITY TESTING METHODS (FULL PROGRAM ORIENTATION, WATER CHEMISTRY, BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES, PHYSICAL STREAM SURVEY, PLANNING) THROUGH A COMBINATION OF ONLINE AND HANDS-ON IN-PERSON OUTDOOR WORKSHOPS. WITH SUPPORT FROM PROGRAM STAFF, THEY RECE

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM GRAND VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY: GREAT LAKES MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE (MWEE) TOOLKIT FOR EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS WILL PROVIDE LESSON PLANS AND SUPPORTING VIRTUAL CONTENT, AND THESE MATERIALS WILL ALLOW TEACHERS TO CONFIDENTLY LEAD THEIR STUDENTS THROUGH MWEES. GROUNDSWELL WILL ACHIEVE THIS BY ORGANIZING TWO WORKSHOPS FOR TWENTY (20) K-8 TEACHERS IN THE KENT AND OTTAWA INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL DISTRICTS. WE WILL FOCUS ON USING THE MWEE RESOURCES THAT GROUNDSWELL HAS CREATED WITH OUR PAST FUNDING THAT ARE DESIGNED TO GET KIDS OUTSIDE TO LEARN. THESE CURRICULUM MATERIALS ARE STORED ON OUR GROWING WEB PAGE, WHICH ALREADY HOSTS MANY OF THE WATERSHED LESSONS AND ACTIVITIES DESIGNED AND USED BY OUR GROUNDSWELL EDUCATORS. WE WILL WORK WITH WITH PARTNERS TO BOTH DOCUMENT THE MWEE PROCESS AND INSTRUCT THE TEACHERS HOW TO USE DIGITAL MEDIA TO CAPTURE THE STORY OF THEIR WATERSHED. FOUR (4) LEAD TEACHERS WILL WORK WITH THEIR 300 STUDENTS OVER THE YEAR TO FOLLOW THE

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM CASE WESTERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY: SMART CITIZEN SCIENCE CURRICULUM DISSEMINATION AND IMPLEMENTATION WILL UTILIZE A MULTI-FACETED STRATEGY AIMING TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM HEALTH OF LAKE ERIE BY ENGAGING CITIZENS AND BROADENING ACCESS TO RELIABLE MECHANISMS TO MEASURE KEY PHYSICAL AND WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS. FOUNDED BY THE CLEVELAND WATER ALLIANCE IN COLLABORATION WITH A LARGE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS, THE SMART CITIZEN SCIENCE INITIATIVE COMBINES STANDARDIZED DATA COLLECTION WITH AN ONLINE DATA PLATFORM TO ALLOW CITIZEN SCIENTISTS OF ALL AGES TO CONTRIBUTE VALUABLE DATA TO A COMMON DATABASE. THIS PROPOSAL TARGETS A SPECIFIC SUBSET OF CITIZEN SCIENTISTS, NAMELY STUDENTS IN JUNIOR HIGH AND HIGH SCHOOL AND THEIR TEACHERS. WE PROPOSE TO DELIVER INTENSIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACROSS MULTIPLE SITES AND SUPPORT UP TO 50 TEACHERS AND 10 LOCAL CHAMPIONS AS THEY IMPLEMENT THREE NEW MODULES IN CLASSROOMS.

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM MICHIGAN TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY: EXPANDING MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR RURAL SCHOOLS - EXPLORING THE GEO-HERITAGE OF LAKE SUPERIOR COASTAL SITES (EXPLORING OUR FOUNDATIONS) WILL ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 15 K-12 TEACHERS AND 800 STUDENTS FROM FIVE COUNTIES IN MICHIGAN'S WESTERN UPPER PENINSULA IN A VARIETY OF MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) THAT WILL SUPPORT UNIQUE STUDENT-DRIVEN STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS. THIS PROJECT ENGAGES  RURAL COMMUNITIES IN MWEES WITH SPECIFIC FOCUS ON THE INTERSECTION OF GEOLOGY, HUMAN RELATIONSHIPS  WITH LANDSCAPE, AND IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ALONG COASTAL SITES ON LAKE SUPERIOR. BUILDING UPON  PREVIOUS SUCCESS RECRUITING RURAL SCHOOL PARTICIPATION, EXPLORING OUR FOUNDATIONS WILL FOSTER GREATER  EARTH SCIENCE AND CLIMATE LITERACY BY EXPANDING TEACHER, SCHOOL, AND COMMUNITY PARTNER RECRUITMENT IN  COASTAL COMMUNITIES ON LAKE SUPERIOR. FURTHER, THIS PROJECT WILL AFFORD IMPROVED EARTH SCIENCE AND  CLIMATE

PROJECT PROPOSED FROM INLAND SEAS EDUCATION ASSOCIATION: GREAT LAKES WATERSHED FIELD COURSE WILL BRING 30 GRADE 4-12 EDUCATORS TO THE THOMAS M. KELLY BIOLOGICAL STATION IN SUTTONS BAY, MI FOR FOUR DAYS OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT EMPHASIZING FIRST-HAND EXPERIENCE WITH REGIONAL CONSERVATION SUCCESS STORIES. PARTICIPANTS WILL VISIT FIELD PROFESSIONALS AT PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS WHO WILL SHARE THEIR WATERSHED EXPERTISE AND INSPIRE TEACHERS TO IMPLEMENT STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS WITH STUDENTS IN THEIR HOME COMMUNITIES. THROUGHOUT THE FOUR DAYS, TEACHERS WILL BE GIVEN TIME TO REFLECT ON LEARNED CONTENT AND INCORPORATE IT INTO A CLASSROOM CURRICULUM PLAN THAT INCLUDES MWEES IN THE FORM OF A STUDENT STEWARDSHIP ACTION PROJECT. THESE MWEES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITH THEIR CLASSROOMS OVER THE FOLLOWING SCHOOL YEAR. THE PROJECT PROPOSED BY GOLDEN GATE NATIONAL PARKS CONSERVANCY THROUGH ITS HUB OF YOUTH ENGAGEMENT, THE CRISSY FIELD CENTER, WILL FOCUS ON DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING A MEANINGFUL RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC THROUGH ITS PROJECT WISE PROGRAM. SINCE 2001, PROJECT WISE (WATERSHEDS INSPIRING STUDENT EDUCATION) HAS PROVIDED SAN FRANCISCO'S DIVERSE HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH WITH MEANINGFUL OUTDOOR EXPERIENCES ACROSS THE ICONIC GOLDEN GATE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. PROJECT WISE PROVIDES VARIOUS PROGRAM OFFERINGS THAT CONNECT BOTH YOUTH AND EDUCATORS TO MEANINGFUL OUTDOOR EXPERIENCES BY ENABLING IMMERSIVE PARTICIPATION IN EDUCATIONAL, STEWARDSHIP, AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES COMBINED WITH COLLABORATIVE HANDS-ON INVESTIGATIVE PROJECTS PRESENTED IN A FINAL SYMPOSIUM TO PEERS, PARK OFFICIALS, AND THE PUBLIC.
